comment.author: 20727502@N00
comment._content: Don't know anything about the gun, but suspect it's housed in the battery built by Doneraile walk in 1891/2. There's a few shots on Flickr of this older gun on Doneraile walk (which may have been retired when the new one was installed). Some other info around and about on the Doneraile battery but little about the gun itself.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/20727502@N00] Moved the photo location thanks to your input!
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: Not sure what type of gun this is, its definitely a breech loaded weapon. I had thought it might be the gun that is still on the Doneraile but that one is a rifled muzzle loader. It may have been the original gun that was installed in the battery in 1891 and probably replaced at sometime later by the more modern gun in the photo. Photo I took a few years ago of the gun at the Doneraile walk, tramore

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: This is an old postcard of the Doneraile Walk, the building on the left is the gun battery, Unfortunately the building is no longer there.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99028520@N00
comment._content:
..here are the same men practising with artillery (presumably near Tramore?). Any input from large gun experts would be very welcome - make, model, era
It is a 4inch or 5inch B.L. (probably the latter) on a ship's pattern Vavasser broadside mounting. 1890s onwards.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/palmerstonforts] Thanks so much! If you have a second, could you just confirm for me - is B.L. = Breech Loading??
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 99028520@N00
comment._content:
B.L. = Breech Loading
M.L.= Muzzle Loading
R.M.L. = Rifled Muzzle Loading
R.B.L. = Rifled Breech Loading
S.B. = Smooth Bore

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/palmerstonforts] Perfect, thanks! Building up quite the military reference library on here - very useful...  :)
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 66246217@N04
comment._content: Waterford Royal Garrison Artillery would have manned these coastal defence batteries.

comment.author: 33577523@N08
comment._content: I doubt if they had anything to do with this particular gun Kildaremark, this was a Coast Guard gun battery, the Coast Guard being at that time a reserve force of the Royal Navy. Also the men shown firing the gun in the above photo are members of The coast Guard.
